question: ['What is the name of the computer model that simulates simulation?']

question: ['What type of system is modeled?']

question: ['What is one aspect of work in this field?']

question: ['What is another aspect of work in this field?']
answer: another aspect of work in this field is the creation of the simulation system itself.

question: ['What is the name of the java-based simulation and animation environment that supports web-based']

question: ['What is the area of interactive parallel computing?']
answer: professor hybinette's interests are in the area of interactive parallel computing in which end-users and the physical environment interact with running, distributed application programs (and affect the programs' execution).

question: ['What is the focus of her research?']
answer: her research has centered on large-scale, high performance, discrete event simulation.

question: ['What does cloning and merge work in?']
answer: work in cloning and merging contributes to improved performance on these systems.

question: ['What is the industry acceptance of semantic web and semantic web processes service oriented architectures?']

question: ['What is the vision of the next generation of the web?']
answer: the semantic web has emerged as the vision of the next generation of the web, in which meaning is associated with web resources (data, documents and services) and represented in a machine processable form.

question: ['What is the oldest, largest and most significant research group in the world?']
answer: lsdis lab in our department is one of the oldest, largest and most significant research group in the world in the emerging area of semantic web and semantic web services/processes.

question: ['What is the core faculty expertise?']

question: ['What is the main focus of the work in ontology development?']
answer: this has resulted in substantial body of the work in ontology development, automatic metadata extraction and semantic annotation (with associated challenges in entity identification/recognition and resolution /disambiguation), semantic annotation of web services (including a w3c submission on wsdl-s) and use of semantics in complete web process life cycle, as well as scalable and high performance query processing and reasoning including rdf query processing and analysis of large rdf graphs for discovery of complex relationships (called semantic associations).

question: ['In real-time systems, many events have specific timing constraints.']
answer: real-time systems in real-time systems, many events have specific timing constraints.

question: ['What happens if the constraints are violated?']
answer: if these constraints are violated, a system failure occurs.

question: ['What are the types of systems used in airplane autopilot systems?']
answer: these types of systems are used in many applications incuding airplane autopilot systems and powerplant controllers.

question: ['What is the timing requirement for the system to be met before it is used?']
answer: because these systems are often used in safety critical applications, it is essential that we can guarantee the timing requirements will be met before the system is used.

question: ['What is the goal of testing all jobs?']

question: ['What is the name of the professor of computer science?']

question: ['What is the main focus of parallel processing?']
answer: parallel processing the parallel processing group is pursuing both the advanced use and the development of parallel processing systems.

question: ['What is the main area of interest for us?']
answer: since parallel processing systems are being used in the most compute-intensive applications, we have been investigating the implications of parallel processing in the areas of interest to us: image processing, robot vision, satellite data processing, matrix reduction, nonlinear wave equations, banded, circulant, and toeplitz systems of equations, multivariable partial differential equations, and vlsi physical design.

question: ['What is the focus of parallel systems?']
answer: since parallel systems are often awkward to quite difficult to implement applications on, we have an interest in improved programming, networking, and development environments for parallel systems.

question: ['What is the name of the parallel algorithms used on pipeline systems?']
answer: we have implemented parallel algorithms on pipeline systems, hypercube systems, and simd systems (the maspar).

question: ['What is the main focus of the robotics research group?']
answer: robotics the main focus of the robotics research group is the development of autonomous mobile robots (amrs).

question: ['What is the primary issue with amrs?']
answer: with amrs there are two primary issues to deal with: (1) cognitive behavior, and (2) motion.

question: ['What is the purpose of cognitive behavior?']
answer: cognitive behavior addresses problem solving using sensory inputs and desired goals.

question: ['What is the name of the movement that involves robotic arm movement?']
answer: motion deals with aspects of movement from simple robotic arm movement to autonomous rovers in unknown environments.

question: ['What is the current focus of the research group?']
answer: cognitive behavior is the current focus of the research group.

question: ['What is the development of an evolutionary computing approach to controller configuration?']
answer: two projects currently underway involve on-board image processing of video camera inputs for decision making, and the development of an evolutionary computing approach to controller configuration (possibly using field programmable gate arrays).

question: ['What is the controller evolution project trying to provide for?']
answer: in addition, the controller evolution project is attempting to provide for automatic (rule directed) behavior specification.

question: ['What is the scalability and efficiency of the models?']
answer: abstract: in the era of "big data", when we design mining and retrieval models for large data (e.g., in the order of billions of nodes/documents) to extract knowledge and patterns, the scalability and efficiency of the models are of critical importance.

question: ['What is the speed of the models when applied to large amounts of data?']
answer: intuitively, as dataset size increases, the models should not just be effective, but must be fast and scalable also (i.e., run-time speed of the models when applied to very large amount of data).

question: ['What is the cost of traditional mining and retrieval models?']
answer: traditional mining and retrieval models tend to get more and more costly to sustain reasonable run-time speed on large data.

question: ['What is the cost-effective and efficient model-based approach for mining and retrieval?']
answer: in this talk, i will describe cost-effective and efficient modeling-based approaches for mining and retrieval on large data.

question: ['How do i illustrate how to achieve high effective mining and retrieval results on massive data?']
answer: i will illustrate how to achieve highly effective mining and retrieval results on massive data, without incurring too much additional computational latency and costs.

question: ['What is the main challenge for this problem?']
answer: i will describe three key challenges (model, metric, and learning) for this problem and present systematic solutions to address the challenges.

question: ['What is the main benefit of this work?']
answer: an implication of this work is that now we can handle large data more elegantly -- maintaining good mining and retrieval effectiveness, without sacrificing run-time efficiency on massive data or requiring too much additional computational and energy resources, thus offering a more attractive and cost-effective solution for mining and retrieval on massive data.

question: ['What is the science of security?']
answer: the science of security: ensuring secure collaboration munindar p. singh north carolina state university abstract : despite sustained research effort in security, current security practice conveys a decidedly ad hoc flavor---find a bug; patch it; find the next bug; and so on.

question: ['What is sometimes termed "engineering"?']
answer: this methodology is sometimes termed "engineering", using the term in the narrow sense of developing solutions to specific problems.

question: ['What is a science of security?']
answer: the past few years have seen a growing push to develop a science of security (sos), viewed as a systematic body of knowledge with strong theoretical and empirical underpinnings that inform the engineering of secure information systems.

question: ['What is sos?']
answer: i introduce sos, briefly describing its key elements.

question: ['What is the term for system of autonomous participants?']
answer: i then motivate some of the foundational challenges of sos from the standpoint of systems of autonomous participants, sometimes termed "systems of systems".

question: ['What is an element of governance of such systems?']

question: ['What is the main reason for the convergence of devices?']
answer: big data, iot, and clouds: research opportunities in disaster management calton pu georgia institute of technology abstract : the ongoing convergence of evolution of devices (internet of things), deployment of large shared infrastructures (computing clouds), and accumulation of big data (sensors and social networks) has created exciting new research challenges.

question: ['What phases of disaster management will we describe?']
answer: we will describe some of these challenges in the three phases of disaster management: preparedness beforehand, emergency response, and recovery afterwards.

question: ['What is the research challenge in quality of service?']
answer: with concrete scenarios, e.g., using for effective information exchange during emergencies, we will discuss the research challenges in quality of service (e.g., real-time response time, high availability and robustness despite widespread failures), and quality of information (e.g., security, privacy, and robustness despite misinformation).

question: ['What are the two main areas of research that require integration and synthesis of results from?']
answer: these research challenges require integration and synthesis of results from several related areas, e.g., sensor networks and social networks as big data producers, and sophisticated models running on clouds as big data consumers.

question: ['What is the purpose of a mission-critical application?']
answer: such integration of heterogeneous and open data sources will require automated methods for reconciling syntactic and semantic differences among semi-structured sources as well as filtering out noises and misinformation in order to achieve the quality of service and quality of information requirements of a mission-critical application such as disaster management.

question: ['What scenario will we use to illustrate these research challenges?']
answer: we will use a concrete multi-hazard scenario (landslides) to illustrate these research challenges and some promising solutions.

question: ['What is the name of the talk titled?']
answer: 26 wednesday, march 26 2014, 2pm aderhold hall g23 deans conference room prof. lois delcambre(professor from computer science department, portland state university) will give a talk titled "bringing structure to (educational) repositories (using techniques from databases and the semantic web)" on wednesday, march 26 from 2-3pm in aderhold hall g23 deans conference room.

question: ['What is the name of modern content management systems?']
answer: abstract: modern content management systems make it easy to build web-based repositories or digital libraries.

question: ['What is the name of the fields that are used to create content types?']
answer: such systems often allow the user to create new content types consisting of any number of named fields; the fields might contain simple values (attributes), references to other content type instances (relationships), or references to files.

question: ['What is the name of the two main metadata fields that repositories may have?']
answer: even when using the same content management system, repositories can differ in structure: some repositories may have a single content type (e.g.,resource) with associated metadata fields (e.g., dublin core metadata fields).

question: ['What are the multiple content types defined by other repositories?']
answer: other repositories may define multiple content types, connected by relationships.

question: ['What is the pedagogical approach used by the instructor?']
answer: we focus here on educational repositories where courses have a rich structure and where each course may have a different structure – based on the pedagogical approach used by the instructor.

question: ['What are the widgets that work for all courses?']
answer: we seek to make it easy to develop generic widgets that will work for all courses, for example.

question: ['What is the domain structure called?']
answer: our approach begins with the definition of small schema fragments that we call domain structures, where the domain structure describes (just) what is needed to support a widget of interest.

question: ['What is the recursive relationship between resources and resources?']
answer: for example, in order to support a hierarchical navigation widget, we use a domain structure with one entity (resource) with a single attribute (title), with a recursive relationship (part-of) that relates resources.

question: ['What do end-users ask to define?']
answer: given a domain structure, we ask domain-savvy end-users to define simple correspondences from the components of the domain structure to their local structure.

question: ['What is the part of relationship between the domain structure and the local units-in-course relationship']
answer: for example, a user might map resource (in the domain structure) to the local course content type, map resource, again, to the local unit content type, and the part-of relationship (in the domain structure) to the local units-in-course relationship.

question: ['What is the goal of the end-user schema mapping?']
answer: in effective, we seek to support end-user schema mapping.

question: ["What widget is a user's course displayed in?"]
answer: once mapped, a user’s course appears in a full-featured navigation widget.

question: ['What is the name of the system that hosts educational repositories?']
answer: we have implemented these ideas in the drupal content management system; we host several educational repositories with generic widgets that support navigation, (selective) cloning and downloading.

question: ['What is the prototype mapping interface?']
answer: the talk will demonstrate the features of our repositories including the widgets and a prototype mapping interface.

question: ['What is the name of the talk that will describe how we formalized the work as a']
answer: the talk will also describe the way in which we have formalized this work as a form of database integration.

question: ['What is the domain structure that supports dynamic, compound faceted browsing for repositories with']
answer: we have extended this work by defining a domain structure that supports dynamic, compound faceted browsing for repositories with simple structure.

question: ['What is the term for a site that uses semantic web technology?']
answer: we envision using our technology over a set of sites (e.g., endpoints) using semantic web technology.

question: ['What is the uga institute for artificial intelligence?']
answer: 40 years of ai achievements at uga monday, october 28 2024, 2 - 5:20pm dogwood room of the uga georgia center what is now the uga institute for artificial intelligence began as a research group in 1984. this event celebrates 40 years of achievements in artificial intelligence at uga with research highlights, open discussions and faculty mixers.

question: ['What is the name of the refreshments available throughout the day?']
answer: refreshments will be available throughout.

question: ['What is the name of the uga ai center?']
answer: schedule 2:00 opening remarks ( s. jack hu , senior vice president for academic affairs and provost; anna stenport, dean, franklin college of arts and sciences) 2:20 history of ai at uga ( don nute , founding director of the uga ai center) 2:35 guest talk ( art recesso , vice chancellor for academic innovation, usg board of regents) 3:00 break 3:10 lightning talks by uga faculty 4:10 break 4:20 breakout sessions 5:20 end guest speaker dr. art recesso serves as the university system of georgia's vice chancellor for academic innovation, overseeing mission-critical strategic initiatives.

question: ["What was art's research scientist at the university of georgia?"]
answer: previously, art was a research scientist and graduate faculty member at the university of georgia, where his research focused on evidential reasoning and probabilistic models for assessing events, including human knowledge development.

question: ['What was the name of the team that led the research and development team?']
answer: he led a research and development team, inventing systems that codify events and generate recommendations for improvement, and launched two technology startups based on these inventions.

question: ["What is art's main focus?"]
answer: as vice chancellor, art spearheads the development of strategic initiatives and new programs designed to expand employment opportunities, transform traditional instructional models, and equip graduates with future-ready knowledge and skills.

question: ['What is the name of the program that he has led?']
answer: he has led the conceptualization and launch of programs targeting rapidly-growing sectors such as data science, cybersecurity, healthcare, and aerospace.

question: ["What is art's current work on ai-related technology?"]
answer: art's current work on ai-related technology centers on a novel approach to knowledge demand and talent development.

question: ['What is the goal of the ai and human-centered process?']
answer: by leveraging ai and human-centered processes, he aims to create a personalized learning system and scalable workforce development model.

question: ['What is the field of computer science?']

question: ['What is the name of the new genetics?']

question: ['What are the methods used to find good solutions to hard problems that are intractable using?']
answer: genetic algorithms and simulation are used to find good (in many cases near-optimal) solutions to hard problems that are intractable using traditional techniques.

question: ['What is the main topic of the research?']

question: ['What are some of the problems that are addressed in image processing?']

question: ['What is the school of computing at the university of georgia conducting an open search for']

question: ['What is the policy for appointment of adjunct faculty?']
answer: policy for appointment of adjunct or courtesy faculty the school of computing (here onwards referred to as soc) may temporarily appoint persons to its faculty ranks as adjunct faculty or courtesy faculty to enhance its research and/or teaching missions.

question: ['What is the term for adjunct faculty at uga?']
answer: adjunct faculty are not employed at uga whereas courtesy faculty have a permanent faculty appointment in another unit at uga.

question: ['What is the name of the appointment that is not attached to the appointment?']
answer: no remuneration from soc is attached to these appointments.

question: ['What is the uga office of the senior vice president for academic affairs and provost?']
answer: these faculty appointments will be made and renewed in compliance with the academic affairs policy manual published by the uga office of the senior vice president for academic affairs and provost.

question: ['What is the majority approval of the faculty?']
answer: all appointments require vote by secret ballot and a majority approval of the faculty.

question: ['How long will each appointment be for each appointment?']
answer: each appointment will be for a period of five years and may be renewed upon request using a process identical to the one followed for the initial appointment.

question: ['What is not required to do with appointments or renewals of adjunct or courtesy faculty?']
answer: while appointments or renewals of adjunct or courtesy faculty tend to be advocated by one or more regular faculty of the soc, this is not required.

question: ['What does the soc have?']
answer: appointed persons do not have voting rights in the affairs of the soc.

question: ['What committee is responsible for the termination of their appointments?']
answer: their appointments may be terminated at any time by the school’s director in consultation with soc’s advisory committee for just cause.

question: ['What is the name of the faculty that is considered to be an adjunct to uga?']
answer: in the event that a courtesy faculty departs from uga upon resignation or retirement, he/she could be considered for an adjunct appointment upon request.

question: ['What is the term for a person seeking a post-admission?']
answer: research adjunct or courtesy faculty eligibility: persons seeking appointment under this category will have a terminal phd degree and clearly establish the potential to be able to significantly contribute toward soc’s research mission.

question: ['What should such persons have a record of research accomplishments that relate to the field of computer']
answer: such persons should have a record of research accomplishments that relate to the field of computer science and a willingness to continue such contributions for mutual benefit.

question: ['What is the name of the person seeking a renewal appointment?']
answer: application: persons seeking such appointment must submit the following to the school’s director for consideration: • a detailed cover letter expressing interest in being appointed under this category either as adjunct or courtesy, accomplishments that make the person eligible, and a clear statement on how the person will contribute toward soc’s research mission • a complete cv listing the full research record so far including past and active grant funding and research-related publications • if this is a renewal appointment, a listing of how the person contributed to soc’s research mission during the person’s most recent past appointment/renewal in this category.

question: ['What is the name of the faculty that will follow the bylaws and norms of so']
answer: expectations: the appointed faculty will follow the bylaws and norms of soc and uga in their dealings with soc faculty, students, and all matters related to the soc.

question: ['What do soc faculty do to demonstrate significant contributions to their research mission?']
answer: appointed faculty can demonstrate significant contributions to the soc’s research mission, e.g., by participating in colloquia as a speaker, serving on multiple graduate student thesis, dissertation or project committees, co-authoring multiple publications with soc faculty and students, participating in soc’s other research activities such as workshops and research days, or collaborating as pi/co-pi on multiple research grant proposals and/or externally funded research projects with soc faculty.

question: ['What is the degree in computer science?']
answer: teaching adjunct or courtesy faculty eligibility: persons seeking appointment under this category will have a terminal phd degree in computer science or a ly related field, and clearly establish the potential to be able to significantly contribute toward soc’s teaching mission.

question: ['What should such persons have a record of teaching accomplishments that relate to the field of computer']
answer: such persons should have a record of teaching accomplishments that relate to the field of computer science and a willingness to continue such contributions for mutual benefit.

question: ['What is the full teaching and research record of the person?']
answer: application: persons seeking such appointment must submit the following to the school’s director for consideration: • a detailed cover letter expressing interest in being appointed under this category, accomplishments that make the person eligible, and a clear statement on how the person will contribute toward soc’s teaching mission • a complete cv listing the full teaching and research record so far including past computer science related course work that was taught, innovative pedagogy developed, and other evidence of instruction • if this is a renewal appointment, a listing of how the person contributed to soc’s teaching mission during the person’s past appointment in this category.

question: ['What is the name of the faculty that will follow the bylaws and norms of so']
answer: expectations: the appointed faculty will follow the bylaws and norms of soc and uga in their dealings with soc faculty, students, and all matters related to the soc.

question: ['What is the name of the faculty that can demonstrate significant contributions to the soc?']
answer: appointed faculty can demonstrate significant contributions to the soc’s teaching mission, e.g., by being an instructor on record for one or more course sections.

question: ['What do soc faculty and students co-author?']
answer: additionally, they can co-author publications related to computer science education with soc faculty and students, or participate in soc’s other teaching-related activities such as instructional committees and workshops, or collaborate as pi/co-pi with soc faculty on multiple grant proposals and/or internally or externally funded projects related to computer science education.

question: ['What is the mission of the uga department?']
answer: mission to offer rigorous undergraduate and graduate degree programs for students seeking careers or further study in the field of computer science; to support faculty research efforts in applied, theoretical, and experimental aspects of computer science; to co-operate with other uga departments and schools on interdisciplinary research, instructional, and service programs; to engage in outreach to the local community and beyond so that computer science can have a positive impact on peoples' lives.

question: ['What is the mission statement of the mission statement?']
answer: contact us visit us mission statement

question: ['What is the name of the student who visits us prospective students?']
answer: visit us prospective students prospective graduate students should contact drs.

question: ['What is the name of the graduate coordinator?']
answer: liming cai or kyu lee, graduate coordinator, at cs-grad-coordinator@uga.edu to arrange a department visit.

question: ['What is the name of the visit that you are visiting?']
answer: please notify at least 1 week in advance of your visit.

question: ["What is the school of computing's main purpose?"]
answer: if you are a prospective undergraduate student interested in learning more about what the school of computing has to offer, we offer informational sessions throughout the year.

answer: more information can be found here .

question: ['What is the name of the school of computing located on south campus?']
answer: the school of computing is primarily housed in the boyd research and education center located on south campus (campus map - boyd rec) .

question: ['Where is visitor parking available?']
answer: visitor parking is available in the south parking deck (parking area s11), located adjacent to the uga hotel and conference center.

question: ['Where is the soule hall stop located?']
answer: from the uga visitor's center, you may take the east/west uga transit bus route to the soule hall stop, located near boyd.

answer: things to keep in mind when scheduling your visit check out the uga academic calendar so that you know when classes are in session.

answer: you may also want to look at the uga master calendar .

question: ['What is the Eastern Standard Time for cs staff?']
answer: cs staff are available between 8:00-5:00pm, eastern standard time, unless otherwise noted.

answer: check in at main office reception, 415 boyd research and education center.

question: ['What is the name of the visitor center that arranges tours of the uga campus?']
answer: tours of the university of georgia campus please contact the university of georgia visitors center to arrange tours of the uga campus.

question: ['What can be scheduled for both weekdays and weekends?']
answer: tours can be scheduled for both weekdays and weekends.

answer: undergraduate students may also want to contact the office of undergraduate admissions in terrell hall and schedule an information session appointment.

answer: applications on april 30th, 2025. note: qualified, and accepted school of computing graduate students can apply for teaching assistantship.

answer: school of computing current and prospective students ( accepted and prospective) can apply for research assistantship.

question: ['What must students provide in their ta application?']
answer: international students must provide qualifying english proficiency score in their ta application to be considered for ta.

question: ['What is the name of the entries that are missing?']
answer: duplicate or incorrect entries, or entries with missing information will not be considered .

question: ['What will not be accepted by email or by duplicate entries?']
answer: we will not be accepting revisions to ta/ra application documents by email or duplicate entries.

question: ['What must be submitted as complete as possible?']
answer: your ta/ra application must be submitted as complete.

question: ['What is the most recent score for english proficiency?']
answer: be prepared to upload your most recent english proficiency score.

answer: please note: a us masters degree does not waive the english proficiency required for ta ship.

answer: phd students are priority, then ms students will be considered.

answer: students will be notified to their uga email, until department needs are met.

question: ['What is the uga placement level 4 toefl speak?']
answer: uga teaching assistants need the following valid english proficiency test scores, to demonstrate english language proficiency ( international students only): toefl speak 26 or higher; ielts speak band score 8.0 or higher; duolingo overall 135 or higher; uga placement level 4 toefl speak 23-25;ielts speak band score 7.0-7.5;duolingo overall 115-130;uga placement level 3 instructor of record: ita-tep level 4 placement and completed gsrc 7770 and * additional requirements ( priority for school of computing ta ships) regular ta : ita-tep level 4 placement and taking gsrc 7770 or level 3 and enrolled in lled 7769 limited duty ta: ita-tep level 3 and taking lled 7769 lab ta's: applying for a ta position means you are willing to perform any assigned duties.

question: ['What is the name of the student who has completed a four-year undergraduate degree at an']
answer: * additional requirements note: if you are an international student (1) from a recognized english-speaking country (as determined by the graduate school), or (2) who has completed a four-year undergraduate degree at an accredited institution in a recognized english-speaking country no more than four years prior to beginning your degree at uga, then you do not need to demonstrate english language proficiency.

question: ['What is the major area of study that the student must pass?']
answer: doctor of philosophy in computer science phd exams comprehensive examination the student must pass the ph.d. comprehensive examination that covers the student's major and minor areas of study.

question: ['What part of the examination is written and oral?']
answer: the examination consists of two parts: a written part and an oral part.

question: ['How many attempts are required to pass the written part?']
answer: students have at most two attempts to pass the written part.

question: ['What is the oral part of the oral part?']
answer: the oral part may not be attempted unless the written part has been passed.

question: ['What is the name of the committee that administers the exams?']
answer: the exams are administered by the student's advisory committee.

question: ['What must have been approved by the student before the exams begin?']
answer: before these exams can begin , the following forms must have been approved submitted by the student and approved by the graduate school.

question: ['How many credit hours does the student have to register for?']
answer: the student is required to register for minimum 3 graduate credit hours in the semester of the comprehensive exam.

question: ['What is the final doctoral program of study written comprehensive examination typically?']
answer: advisory committee for doctoral candidates final doctoral program of study written comprehensive examination typically, each member of the advisory committee will prepare a multi-part question relevant to the students area of advanced study.

question: ['What is the name of the examination given to the student?']
answer: these questions will be given to the student in the form of a take-home examination.

question: ['What is the name of the exam that is usually followed by a follow-up question?']
answer: oral comprehensive examination typically, this exam consists of follow-up questions to the written comprehensive examination.

question: ["How long before the exam should the oral comprehensive exam be provided to the graduate coordinator's office"]
answer: the oral comprehensive exam should be provided to graduate coordinator's office by the student at least two weeks in advance of the exam .

answer: contact the graduate coordinator/graduate coordinator assistant at cs-grad-coordinator@uga.edu to make the announcement to the graduate school.

answer: the graduate coordinator's office completes the comprehensive exam announcement form (g118) in gradstatus at least 2 weeks in advance.

answer: this exam requires that all members of the advisory committee be present and is open to both school faculty and graduate students.

answer: graduate students may request by email to cs-grad-coordinator@uga.edu to announce the exam to cs faculty.

question: ['What is the primary focus requirement?']

question: ['What is the primary focus requirement?']
answer: in particular, coursework taken to satisfy the preliminary focus requirement may not be used to satisfy any portion of the primary focus requirement, and vice versa.

question: ['What is the core curriculum?']
answer: core curriculum (preliminary focus item #1) at least one course from each of the following three groups must be taken: group 1: theory csci 6470 algorithms csci 6480 approximation algorithms csci 6610 automata and formal languages group 2: software design csci 6050 software engineering csci 6370 database management csci 6570 compilers group 3: system design csci 6720 computer systems architecture csci 6730 operating systems csci 6760 computer networks: technology and application csci 6780 distributed computing systems the core curriculum consists of a total of 12 graduate credit hours .

question: ['What is the core competency foundational computer science knowledge in the core areas?']
answer: core competency foundational computer science knowledge (core competency) in the core areas (groups 1, 2, and 3, above) must be exhibited by each student and certified by the student’s advisory committee.

question: ['What is the name of the core curriculum?']
answer: this takes the form of achievement in core curriculum and completion of a short essay in their chosen area of research demonstrating technical writing and organization skills.

question: ['What is the core competency of the ph.d. program?']
answer: students entering the ph.d. program with a previous graduate degree sufficient to cover this basic knowledge will need to work with their advisory committee to certify their core competency.

question: ['What is the primary focus requirement for students entering the ph.d. program?']
answer: students entering the ph.d. program without sufficient graduate background to certify core competency must fulfill the preliminary focus requirement, and then pursue certification with their advisory committee.

question: ['What must be achieved for the three core courses?']
answer: a grade average of at least 3.56 (e.g., a-, a-, b+) must be achieved for the three core courses.

question: ['What is the grade average for students below the average?']
answer: students below this average may take an additional core course and achieve a grade average of at least 3.32 (e.g., a-, b+, b+, b).

answer: core competency is certified by the unanimous approval of the student's advisory committee as well as the approval by the graduate coordinator.

question: ['How many credit hours can be included in the remaining 4 credit hours?']

question: ['What is the name of the csci 8990 that may not be used to']

question: ["What is the primary focus item #4 of the student's dissertation?"]

question: ['What is the name of the professor of genetics?']
answer: jessica kissinger distinguished research professor of genetics courtesy professor of computer science ph.d.: indiana university, 1995 research focus: how do eukaryotic and organellar genome sequences evolve?

question: ['What is the biology of genome evolution?']
answer: our lab is interested in parasite genomics and the biology of genome evolution.

question: ['What is the lateral gene transfer of parasitic eukaryotes?']
answer: the nuclear and organellar genome sequences of parasitic eukaryotes are often highly-reduced, devoid of recognizable mobile elements and riddled with intracellular and lateral gene transfers.

question: ['What is the aim of our approach?']
answer: our approach is to apply molecular, computational and phylogenetic tools to the analysis of complete parasite genome sequences.

question: ['What is the system biology of host-pathogen interactions?']
answer: projects include the development of tools for data integration, data mining, comparative genomics and the systems biology of host-pathogen interactions.

question: ['What is the name of the expert on autonomous decision making?']
answer: in the area of ai, he is an expert on autonomous decision making with specific interests in decision making under uncertainty in multiagent settings.

question: ['What is the name of prof. doshi?']
answer: in robotics, prof. doshi investigates ways to make learning by observing pragmatic for robots and is an expert on inverse reinforcement learning.

question: ['What is the name of the method used to study slam in occluded']
answer: he also studies methods for slam in occluded, multi-robot settings.

question: ['What is the term for the semantic web?']
answer: his past research experience also includes the semantic web and specifically in ontology alignment and learning; and in services-oriented computing, specifically in composing web services and adapting the compositions.

question: ['What is the focus of the interactive pomdp framework?']
answer: in collaboration with prof. piotr gmytrasiewicz at uic, prof. doshi co-pioneered the interactive pomdp (i-pomdp) framework , which complements the predominant focus of previous multiagent research on team decision making.

question: ["What is i-pomdp's subjective perspective?"]
answer: i-pomdp departs from several traditional game-theoretic solution concepts (such as equilibria) and its subjective perspective permits a natural consideration of issues related to interactive epistemology (nested modeling) and computability (finite nesting) in decision making.

question: ['What is the name of the i-pomdp community that is well recognized as leading']
answer: i-pomdps are now well recognized within the multiagent community as a leading framework for decision making in complex, general settings.

question: ['What is the name of the i-pomdps used by researchers?']
answer: recent use cases of i-pomdps by researchers testify to its significance and growing appeal.

question: ['What is the purpose of the simulations?']
answer: they are being used to explore strategies for countering money laundering by terrorists, enhanced to include trust levels for facilitating defense simulations, and building empirical models for simulating human behavior pertaining to strategic thought and action.

question: ['What is the ai journal published by prof. doshi?']
answer: survey articles published by prof. doshi in the ai magazine and the ai journal offer easy readings for a contextual understanding of this framework.

question: ['What is the name of the repository that thinc lab maintains?']
answer: thinc lab also maintains a one-stop repository of all papers related to the i-pomdp framework.

question: ['What award did doshi receive for his work related to i-pomdps?']
answer: in 2011, prof. doshi received uga's creative research medal for his work related to i-pomdps, which acknowledges exceptional achievements in creativity and research by uga faculty.

question: ['What would do prof. doshi want robots to learn?']
answer: prof. doshi would like to see robots learn tasks simply by observing others perform them.

question: ['What is the purpose of his research?']
answer: toward this ambitious goal, his research investigations focus on generalizing inverse reinforcement learning (irl) to operate in contexts involving noisy sensor models and where portions of the observed task may be occluded from view.

question: ['What is a recent survey article published by him and his doctoral student?']
answer: a recent survey article published by him and his doctoral student offers an informative review and comparison of various irl methods and their extensions.

question: ['What is the purpose of the research?']
answer: this research is being evaluated by teaching collaborative robotic manipulators on a produce processing line to accurately sort onions.

question: ['What was the name of the pandemic?']
answer: using robotics to help sort onions on georgia farms wednesday, march 27, 2024 - 8:55am image: during the pandemic, labor problems became acute on many farms in georgia and across the country.

question: ['What was the global supply chain severely affected?']
answer: farms once staffed by humans to bring produce from the field to stores for purchase were suddenly short-staffed, and the global supply chain was severely impacted.

question: ['What is the team of researchers led by?']
answer: a team of researchers led by school of computing professor prashant doshi is designing collaborative robots to mitigate some of these potential challenges.

question: ['What is the name of the unit of the college of agricultural and environmental sciences?']
answer: working with uga’s vidalia onion and vegetable research center , a unit of the college of agricultural and environmental sciences , and a&m farms in lyons, georgia, they have tested a robotic arm in the task of sorting fresh vidalia onions from those suffering blemishes.

question: ['What is the system capable of sorting the good from?']
answer: combining a robotic arm with cameras and an ai trained to recognize the good and bad produce, the system can pick up onions, view it, and sort the good from the bad.

question: ['What type of task has been shown progress in the project?']
answer: the project has shown progress in a type of task known as “pick-inspect-place.” robots in agriculture or manufacturing have long been involved in picking and placing tasks.

question: ['What is the element of inspecting using computer vision?']
answer: here, researchers have added the element of inspecting using computer vision, as well.

question: ['What is the name of the doctoral student on the project?']
answer: “there are basically two ai models,” said prasanth suresh, a doctoral student on the project.

question: ['What is one that teaches the robot the behavior and detects the object using vision?']
answer: “there’s one that teaches the robot the behavior and one that detects the object using vision.

question: ['What is the idea of ai model that will detect the object?']
answer: the second ai model will detect the object and instruct the proper behavior—r inspection for blemishes on good onions or throwing blemished onions in the waste.” the idea, doshi said, is not to eliminate these professions for human workers, but to provide options, protect the job from labor shortages and to upskill workers into positions that require less strenuous conditions.

question: ['What is the name of the workers who work through high heat, dust, or other conditions?']
answer: “often, these workers work through high heat, dust, or other conditions,” he said.

question: ['What is the name of the worker who is not a worker?']
answer: “we are not trying to replace this worker.

question: ["What is the goal of dr. cotterell's project?"]
answer: each grant funds a project related to update the csci 1302 textbook in 2025. dr. cotterell’s project seeks to make the textbook more accessible and user-friendly by transitioning existing materials over to a new website environment that affords better searchability and cross-linking via support for open document formats and the integration of new and existing open-source software projects.

question: ["What is the goal of dr. barnes's project?"]
answer: dr. barnes’s project seeks to author additional examples, questions, and sample solutions to be included directly in the textbook.

question: ['What is the goal of both projects?']
answer: the overall goal of both projects is to reduce barriers to entry so that the content is more approachable and so that students can practice the material sooner and as they go.

question: ['What is the purpose of the grants?']
answer: these grants will also fund an external faculty evaluator to help contribute pedagogical feedback to the authors as well as 2-4 undergraduate student workers to help dr. barnes and dr. cotterell test changes, help review revisions, and other tasks related to completing the goals of each project.

question: ['What is the purpose of the project?']
answer: this will provide an excellent opportunity for those student workers to positively contribute to student success in uga’s school of computing and gain valuable experience by working on the projects.

question: ['What is the name of the school that will be jointly administered by the franklin college']

question: ['What is the president of the university of georgia committed to creating synergies']

question: ['What is the name of the task force on the future of computing?']
answer: “i am excited about the positive impact the school of computing will have on research and education in the stem disciplines at uga.” the establishment of the school of computing stems from the work of a seven-member task force on the future of computing that included faculty and academic leaders from both the franklin college and the college of engineering.

question: ['Who was the task force chaired by?']
answer: the task force was charged by provost s. jack hu and chaired by marisa pagnattaro, who was recently named vice president for instruction.

question: ['What is the college of engineering?']

answer: “the strategic hiring of new faculty will create new opportunities for undergraduate and graduate instruction while also supporting research in areas that are of strategic importance to our state and world.” rising student demand enrollment in computer science courses has grown rapidly in recent years, and the college of engineering is uga’s fastest growing college.

question: ['What program will be administered by the school of computing?']
answer: the school of computing will administer the university’s bachelor’s, master’s, and ph.d. programs in computer science as well as the master’s program in cybersecurity and privacy.

question: ['What is the projected growth in stem-related occupations?']
answer: “its new, elevated status as the school of computing reflects the vital role of computer science in our university and in our world.” nationally, employment in stem-related occupations is projected by the bureau of labor statistics to grow 8% through 2029, which is more than double the 3.4% growth projected for non-stem occupations.

answer: the other criteria include: academic record (gpa); caliber and reputation of the applicant’s institution(s); applicant’s academic preparation (i.e., the courses taken in previous degree program(s)); toefl score (ibt) or ielts score; letters of recommendation.

question: ['What is the name of the letter that is written in the letter?']

question: ['What is the president of girls who code?']
answer: i see this growth as a massive success because of the way we can serve the students in our partner schools,” said apurva sharma, the current president of girls who code.

question: ['What is the basic basic of binary?']
answer: “without our organization, it would be very difficult for the girls in athens-clarke county to find opportunities with such personalized mentorship on particular, current, and sophisticated computer science skills.” the interactive workshops cover a range of topics to introduce students to foundational and cutting-edge computing concepts, including: building websites with html, css, javascript, ai game design, programming sphero robots, understanding cybersecurity and digital privacy, and the basics of binary.

answer: the workshops are carefully curated to build confidence, spark curiosity, and give participants the ability to gain practical skills and insights into the possibilities of technology.

question: ['How many undergraduate majors and minors are held together by a common commitment to preserving']
answer: the english department at the university of georgia is a diverse scholarly community of more than 40 faculty, 70 graduate students, and more than 400 undergraduate majors and minors held together by a common commitment to preserving, transmitting, and extending the rich cultural legacy of the english language.

question: ['What skills are at the core of our discipline?']
answer: at the core of our discipline lie the complex skills of reading and writing, and though these can be productively applied to a wide range of professional goals our own work as scholars and teachers strives to deepen our understanding of the critical and creative imagination.

question: ['What is the benefit of a sympathetic participation in the verbal worlds of other times and']
answer: a sympathetic participation in the verbal worlds of other times and places, drawing on the full range of linguistic tools, historical knowledge, and interpretive experience at our disposal, allows our students to enhance their appreciation for expressive possibility.

question: ['What is the central role that language plays in the preservation of human institutions?']
answer: the diversity of the faculty's interests and research methods helps ensure that an english major at the university of georgia develops a sophisticated, practical grasp of the central role that language plays in the preservation of human institutions.

question: ['What is the focus of the graduate faculty in african american and multicultural studies?']
answer: the graduate faculty in african american and multicultural studies conduct research and teaching focused on the literature, culture, and music of people of color in the united states.

question: ['What is the name of the study that we do in african american studies?']
answer: our particular strengths are in african american and native american studies.

question: ['What is the harlem renaissance?']
answer: our areas of specialization within african american studies include slavery and abolition, the post-bellum, pre-harlem era, the harlem renaissance, and the chicago renaissance, along with the study of performances of race and gender, african american and black feminist criticism and theory, contemporary african american prose and poetry, and the craft of writing.

question: ['What is the relationship between native and chicano/a cultures at the border?']
answer: our areas of specialization within native american studies include native american renaissance, contemporary native literatures of north america, native film, american indian literary nationalism, native women writers, and the relationship between native and chicano/a cultures at the u.s./mexico border.

question: ['What is the institute for African american studies?']
answer: faculty in this area also hold joint appointments or affiliations with a variety of programs at the university of georgia, including the institute for african american studies, the institute of native american studies, latin american and caribbean studies institute, the institute for women's studies, and the creative writing program.

question: ['What is the name of the study that a graduate student can earn?']
answer: graduate students in african american and multicultural studies can earn additional certificates in women’s studies and native american studies.

question: ['What is the name of the group that is a student that is a student?']
answer: students participate in a variety of opportunities to conduct research outside of the classroom, share their writing, and join networks of scholars and students across disciplines.

question: ['What is the name of the review that students serve as editorial assistants?']
answer: at the langston hughes review , students serve as editorial assistants and manuscript reviewers, and they have published revised conference and seminar papers for publication in this journal.

question: ['What is the civil rights digital library initiative?']
answer: graduate students in the area can work in unpaid research assistantships to develop instructional components of the civil rights digital library initiative , an online project that features archival footage from the university's walb and wsb newsfilm collections.

question: ['What is the name of the new georgia encyclopedia?']
answer: research assistants for the crdl have published essays on african american literature, film, and culture for the new georgia encyclopedia and in reference volumes for national presses.

question: ['What is the name of the group that has helped organize and/or participated in recent events?']
answer: additionally, graduate students have helped organize and/or participated in recent events such as new voices in american literature: a multicultural symposium (2007), native american literary nationalism conference (2007), black poets lean south: a cave canem symposium (2008), native american & indigenous studies association (2008), and beyond the movement: global and contemporary freedom struggles (2009).

question: ['What is the national list for the association of the study of american indian literature?']
answer: faculty in the area also administer two list-serves - asail, the national list for the association of the study of american indian literature, and msis-l, a regional list for multicultural studies scholars - which both provide forums where our students can ask research questions, get assistance with problems in the classroom, stay abreast of current debates and publications, and find calls for papers for conferences and publications.

question: ['What is the name of the library that contains special collections in african american and multicultural studies?']
answer: a resource page for graduate students working in native american literature has also been assembled: na grad links the university libraries contain many special collections in african american and multicultural american studies.

question: ['What is the name of the foot soldier project for civil rights studies?']
answer: the richard b. russell library houses photographs, interview transcripts, documentary films, and other archival materials of the foot soldier project for civil rights studies .

question: ['What is the walter j. brown media archive?']
answer: the digital library of georgia of georgia includes historic african american newspapers and books, blues and vaudeville selections from african american theater, southeastern native american documents, including a digitized, searchable version of the cherokee phoenix, and other relevant databases.in addition to news film of the civil rights era, the walter j. brown media archives contains amateur movies, peabody award-winning documentary programs, and television shows featuring topics in african american and native american studies.

question: ['What is the subject guide for African American studies?']
answer: finally, we provide access to such electronic resources as african american biographical databases, 19th-century african american newspapers, african american poetry, ethnic newswatch, and the native american studies subject guide.

question: ['What department of english accepts into its m.a.']
answer: the university of georgia department of english accepts into its m.a.

question: ['What is the name of the program that students present a b.a.']
answer: programs students who present a b.a.

question: ['What is a solid grade-point average in english courses?']
answer: in english or its equivalent, and a solid undergraduate grade-point average (at least a 3.0), especially in english courses (3.65 or better), as well as positive letters of recommendation and other evidence of scholastic achievement, including proficiency in writing.

question: ['What is the name of the program that encourages students to take courses in?']
answer: program at the university of georgia encourages students to take courses in a variety of areas to broaden and deepen their literary and critical backgrounds.

question: ['What is the minimum of three hours of credit required to represent research on their thesis?']
answer: the program offers a two-year degree, which requires 30 hours of course work (one course is three hours of credit), at least three hours of which must represent research on their thesis.

question: ['What language must students demonstrate reading knowledge?']
answer: students must also demonstrate reading knowledge of an approved foreign language.

question: ['What is the core requirement of one course?']
answer: students will complete a core requirement of one course from each of three literary divisions: students will also specialize in an area of concentration (defined as three related courses) from one of our thematic arcs.

question: ['What is the name of the course that students will complete their study program with?']
answer: students will round out their program of study with a course from another thematic arc plus two electives.

question: ['What is the name of the advisory committee that helps students plan appropriate courses of study?']
answer: major professors and advisory committees help students plan appropriate courses of study and otherwise offer advice and encouragement.

question: ['What is the portfolio of three essays written in their courses?']
answer: at the end of their course work, students must pass an oral examination covering their course of study, a portfolio of three essays written in their courses, and a selective list of major works studied.

question: ["What is the name of the major professor of the student's major professor?"]
answer: the student's major professor will offer guidance on selecting the papers and compiling the reading list.

question: ["How many pages of thesis project is submitted for approval in the student's final semester of study"]
answer: thesis project of about 50 pages is submitted for approval in the student's final semester of study.

question: ['What is the name of the paper that may be developed from?']
answer: it may be developed from a class paper or be the product of original research and study.

question: ['What is a pedagogical study?']
answer: it may take the form of an academic thesis (necessary for those considering a ph.d. program here or elsewhere); a pedagogical study, such as a curriculum or a teaching approach to a text; or a project employing methods from one of the concentrations, such as a computer program or an edition.

question: ['What is the term for the thesis?']
answer: all options require a written component, referred to institutionally as the thesis.

question: ['What is the main focus of the thesis project?']
answer: the thesis project is prepared under the guidance of the major professor and advising committee.

question: ['What is the final form of the thesis project approved?']
answer: once the thesis project is approved in final form, the student must pass a one-hour oral examination, given by the candidate's committee.

question: ['What is an applicant must hold in english?']
answer: to qualify for admission, an applicant must hold at least a b.a., and preferably an m.a., in english; have a high grade-point average (at least 3.0 in undergraduate studies), especially in english courses (3.65 or better in undergraduate english classes).

question: ['What should applicants provide?']
answer: in addition, applicants should provide supportive letters of recommendation and other evidence of scholastic achievement, including proficiency in writing.

question: ['What is the name of the program that most applicants are admitted in?']
answer: while most of the applicants who are admitted in the ph.d. program already hold a master's degree in english, applicants with exceptional undergraduate records may be admitted directly into the doctoral program without an m.a.

question: ['What is the name of the program that students enter the program with?']
answer: students entering the program with the m.a.

question: ["How many hours of course work will be required before admission to a candidate's candidacy"]
answer: will take a minimum of 27 hours of course work (one course is three hours of credit) before admission to candidacy, three hours of which must be dissertation research (9300).

question: ["How many hours of course work does a bachelor's degree take before admission to a"]
answer: students entering the program with a bachelor's degree will take a minimum of 45 hours of course work, exclusive of research hours, before admission to candidacy.

question: ['What is the name of the program that allows students to select courses and areas for examination?']
answer: the program allows students to select courses and areas for examination with the advice and direction of a major professor and advisory committee.

question: ['What is the term for the first advisor?']
answer: for each entering student, the graduate coordinator serves as the first advisor and then appoints a temporary major advisor, who provides counsel on course work and general directions for study.

question: ['What is the name of the major professor that should be selected before the end of the first year']
answer: before the end of the first year of study, the student should select a major professor and constitute an advisory committee.

question: ['What is the chair of the advisory committee?']
answer: the chair of the advisory committee (the major professor) will usually be the prospective director of the dissertation.

question: ['What is the main reason for success of their program of study?']
answer: for many students the success of their program of study depends on a and productive relationship with the major professor.

question: ['What is the student who enters with an m.a.']
answer: ordinarily, the student who enters with an m.a.

question: ['What year does the dissertation end?']
answer: spends the first two years of study completing course work, the third year studying for the written and oral examinations, and the fourth year completing the dissertation.

question: ['What is the student who enters with a b.a.']
answer: the student who enters with a b.a.

question: ['What year does the final year of the dissertation end?']
answer: devotes the first three years to course work, the fourth year to studying for the examination, and the final year to completing the dissertation.

question: ['What is the name of the program that some students move through?']
answer: some students move through the program at a faster pace.

question: ['What is the name of the student advisory committee that may recommend or require specific courses?']
answer: there are no required courses, but the student's advisory committee may recommend or require specific courses that provide a foundation for the dissertation, address particular gaps in a student's preparation, or round out a special area of concentration.

question: ['What is the requirement for research skills?']
answer: doctoral students must fulfill the research skills requirement, which can be done so--as detailed in the graduate student handbook--in a variety of ways.

question: ['What is the second way to demonstrate reading knowledge of two foreign languages?']
answer: the first way to to demonstrate reading knowledge of two foreign languages; the second way is to demonstrate proficiency (a higher level of language fluency) in one foreign language; the third way is to demonstrate reading knowledge of one foreign language and competence in specified research skills.

question: ["What is the student's advisory committee responsible for?"]
answer: the student's advisory committee must approve the language or languages offered, and the graduate committee must approve any proposed set of research skills (such a plan of study should involve substantial study taken at the graduate level outside the english department).

question: ['What is the name of the degree that is required for new graduate students?']
answer: new graduate students should plan to satisfy this portion of their degree requirements as soon after matriculation as possible.

question: ['What is the final examination of the student?']
answer: no later than the end of the third year, the student will complete his or her written and oral comprehensive examinations.

question: ["What is the student's advisory committee appointed by?"]
answer: these examinations are administered by a three-member examining committee (the student's advisory committee) appointed by the graduate coordinator in consultation with the student's major professor.

question: ['What is the name of the three areas chosen from?']
answer: the examinations cover three areas chosen from the approved areas listed in the graduate student handbook by the student and approved by the student's advisory committee.

question: ['What is the georgiana collection?']

question: ['What is the focus of the mfa?']
answer: our students are accomplished poets, fiction writers, essayists, translators, and interdisciplinary artists who are ready to move beyond the studio focus of the mfa to a more intensive program of literary study.

question: ['What is the main focus of my research?']

question: ['What is the guiding light in these inquiries?']
answer: while the pursuit of these fundamental questions has guided me through several related academic fields (modernist studies, comparative literature, american studies, cold war studies, continental philosophy, and translation theory), the guiding light in these inquiries has always been the same concern with the political functions of literature amidst the permanent crises of modernity.

question: ['What was the first book of the naked communist?']
answer: my first book, the naked communist (fordham up, 2012), explores the ways literature participated in the constitution of the global imaginaries of early-cold war us mainstream culture in the 1950s.

question: ['What was the first time in the history of the west?']
answer: by dividing the globe into three separate “worlds,” this cultural imaginary tried to contain a historical crisis that, for the first time in the history of the west, threatened the entire globe with the real possibility of human extinction.

question: ['What was the idea of modernism reconfigured to provide an ideological justification for?']
answer: i tried to demonstrate that in this historical context the idea of “modernism” was reconfigured to provide an ideological justification for a specific type of post-colonial imperialism whose long-term effects are still detectable today.

question: ['What is the focus of the book that i am currently exploring in my current work?']
answer: the conclusions of this book set me on a broader research agenda that i am currently exploring in my current work.

question: ['What is the name of the epochal catastrophe that threatens us all?']
answer: my second monograph, worldlessness after heidegger (edinburgh up, 2020), examines the way the concept of “worldlessness” has emerged in 20 th -century continental philosophy as the standard name for the epochal catastrophe that supposedly threatens us all with the loss of our humanity.

question: ['What is the looming threat of ecological disaster?']
answer: according to this intellectual tradition, technological development, imperialism, globalization, the generalization of war-like conditions over the globe, and the looming threat of ecological disaster have created a historical situation in which humanity is simultaneously ever more technologically connected and is increasingly incapable of constructing a shared common “world.” this lost sense of a shared community, then, supposedly explains the rise of authoritarian political tendencies today.

question: ['What is the book argues that some of the most influential intellectual innovations of the 20th century']
answer: the book argues that some of the most influential intellectual innovations of the 20 th century like phenomenology, psychoanalysis, and deconstruction should be seen as fundamentally political responses to this historical situation and calls for affirmative definitions of “worldlessness.” in addition to traditional forms of academic literary and cultural criticism, i am also deeply committed to editing and translation.

question: ['What was the name of the student that i got involved with editing?']
answer: i got involved with editing while i was still a graduate student at suny/buffalo.

question: ['What did i always consider these opportunities to have been foundational experiences of my education?']
answer: i have always considered these opportunities to have been foundational experiences of my education as they showed me the force and necessity of creating intellectual communities around pressing contemporary questions.

question: ['What was the idea of the book series provocations?']
answer: the book series, provocations , that i co-edit with marco abel for the university of nebraska press was conceived in the same spirit as it publishes short polemical interventions into contemporary academic debates.

question: ['What is the practice of translation?']
answer: my theoretical interest in translation has always been rooted in the practice of translation, which has been my constant preoccupations for the entirety of my academic career.

question: ['What is the translation of continental philosophy?']
answer: since it is impossible to separate the theory from the actual experience of translation, over the years i have also specialized in the translation of continental philosophy and critical theory.

question: ['What is the name of the book that was written by rodolphe gasché?']
answer: i am the translator and co-translator of three books: rodolphe gasché’s georges bataille: phenomenology and phantasmatology (stanford university press, 2012), peter szendy’s all ears: the aesthetics of espionage (fordham university press, 2017), and fethi benslama’s thinking revolution: writings on insubmission (co-translated with nathan gorelick, forthcoming from bloomsbury).

question: ['What is the name of the book that j. d. sargan is']
answer: j. d. sargan (he/him) specializes in medieval english literature, paleography, codicology, and the history of the book.

question: ['What is the name of the book that is routledge handbook to the history of']
answer: he is the co-editor of the routledge handbook to the history of the book in medieval western europe, 650–1550 (forthcoming 2025) and of the medieval volume of a cultural history of trans lives (forthcoming 2027).

question: ["What is the name of the three spheres that dr sargan'"]
answer: dr sargan's research occupies three overlapping spheres.

question: ['What is the multiplicity of partial literacies exhibited by readers of manuscripts']
answer: his first book project, reading early middle english books , is invested the multiplicity of partial literacies exhibited by readers of manuscripts from 1066–1300.

question: ['What is the term for reading?']
answer: in it he uses critical approaches to non-verbal evidence—marks, dirt, and the haptics of binding—to show that reading was a social act that extended the written word to those far beyond the limits of traditional considerations of literacy.

question: ["What is dr sargan's interest in?"]
answer: his interest in the haptics and handling of books lead to dr sargan’s work investigating binding structures using scientific imaging.

question: ['What is the use of micro-ct in researching no longer extant binding structures?']

question: ['What is the name of the student who is interested in uga?']

question: ['What has been the result of both of these research areas?']
answer: finally, both of these research areas have been a prompt to critical thinking about methodology.

question: ['What genres have been particularly egregious in disseminating destructive stereotypes']
answer: fascinatingly, genres that have been especially egregious in disseminating destructive stereotypes about indigenous peoples (like horror, science fiction, animation, westerns, and sport movies) have been appropriated by indigenous filmmakers for native ends.

question: ['What is the book argues that indigenous north american filmmakers mobilize narrative and visual trope']

question: ['What is the name of the professor sujata iyengar*?']
answer: sujata iyengar* (ph.d., stanford university, 1998), professor, specializes in english renaissance literature, shakespearean adaptation and appropriation, and book history and arts.

question: ["What was the first book of dr. iyengar's first book"]
answer: dr. iyengar's first book was the germinal monograph shades of difference: mythologies of skin color and race in early modern england ( university of pennsylvania press , 2005); other books include shakespeare's medical language (bloomsbury/arden, 2011), several print and digital co-authored textbooks, the edited collections disability, health, and happiness in the shakespearean body (routledge, 2015) and shakespeare and global appropriation (routledge, 2020), and shakespeare and adaptation theory (bloomsbury/arden, 2022).

question: ['What is the name of the peer-reviewed essays?']
answer: peer-reviewed essays include an award-winning article in elh (2002), and others in shakespeare quarterly, shakespeare survey , literature/film quarterly , shakespeare, postmodern culture , medieval and renaissance drama in england, cahiers élisabéthains and elsewhere as well as peer-reviewed chapter contributions to collections from the folger shakespeare library , purdue university press , the university of pennsylvania press , the u niversity of toronto press , ashgate , palgrave , cambridge university press, oxford university press, and routledge .

question: ['What year did dr. iyengar spend on a second discipline fellowship']

question: ['What is the name of the poem that inspired her to begin writing?']
answer: her year in the art school inspired her to begin writing poetry as well as to teach it; her free and formal lyrics have been published in a few juried "little magazines" in print and online, including punctum press's lunch ; mezzo cammin ; upstart crow ; unsplendid ; and measure .

question: ['What award did iyengar win for excellence in teaching?']
answer: a winner of the special sandy beaver award for excellence in teaching and of fellowships from the office of service-learning and the office of online learning at uga, dr. iyengar likes to collaborate with units and departments from all over campus and, most recently, internationally.

question: ['What is the uga at oxford program?']
answer: she has developed experiential, interdisciplinary, service-learning, hybrid, and "hyflex" courses, delivered guest-lectures, or team-taught workshops at the graduate and undergraduate levels with faculty from: the gru/uga medical partnership in athens; the college of public health; the health and medical journalism program; the department of history; the uga at oxford program; uga's sustainable development program; the college of education; the uga libraries; the state botanical gardens; and with local elementary, middle, and adult education classes.

question: ['What is the name of the conference that she has been invited to speak about?']

question: ['What was the first prize in the "best new journal" category?']
answer: with the late christy desmet, dr. iyengar co-founded the online, peer-reviewed, multimedia, scholarly journal borrowers and lenders: the journal of shakespeare and appropriation , which won first prize in the "best new journal" category from the council of editors of learned journals (2007).

question: ['What year did the journal celebrate its tenth anniversary?']
answer: the journal celebrated its tenth anniversary in november 2015 and, with the support of the willson center for humanities and arts, the office of the provost, the uga libraries, the graduate school, the uga symposium on the book, and the departments of english and theatre and film studies, co-hosted an international conference, open to the public, in athens on " appropriation in an age of global shakespeare ."

question: ['What is the name of the journal that dr. iyengar has ']

question: ['From what year was the journal published?']
answer: from 2005-2018 the journal was sustained by the uga english department in partnership with the willson center and was co-edited by dr. iyengar and christy desmet; from 2018-2022 it was sustained by the uga libraries and the willson center and co-edited by dr. iyengar, dr. matthew kozusko (ursinus college) and dr. louise geddes (adelphi university); from 2022-2024 the journal was published in partnership with the arizona center for medieval and renaissance studies (acmrs), the texas digital library, and the willson center, and co-edited by dr. iyengar, dr. geddes, dr. kozusko, and dr. vanessa corredera (andrews university); from 2025, the journal will be sustained solely by acmrs and the texas digital library and co-edited by drs.

question: ['What is the monograph about shakespeare and the art of the book?']

question: ['What is the name of the book that dr. david mark diamond teaches?']
answer: dr. david mark diamond teaches and writes about eighteenth-century british literature and the early black atlantic, with particular emphasis on the role that religion plays in the formation of imperial global imaginaries.

question: ['What was the process by which christian belief came unbound from singular doct']
answer: his current research examines literary responses to secularization, or the process by which christian belief came unbound from singular doctrinal orthodoxy and this newly liberalized religion was grafted more and more fully onto the european ambition of racialized planetary domination.

question: ["What is diamond's first book?"]
