question: ['What are the core goals of all fyw courses?']
answer: all fyw courses share a set of core goals, or learning outcomes, which are detailed below and are also reflected in the program grading rubric and capstone electronic portfolio assignment.

question: ['What is the main genre of academic discourse that students will encounter in many courses across the curriculum?']
answer: english 1101 focuses on informational, analytical, and argumentative writing (the principal genres of academic discourse that students will encounter in many courses across the curriculum), and on research skills and critical thinking.

question: ['What is the name of the class that is taught in english 1101?']
answer: there are different varieties of english 1101 classes and instructors design their own syllabi.

question: ['What is the name of the school that students must do to get into english 1101?']
answer: students must either place into english 1101 or pass out of the academic enhancement program.

question: ['What are the results statements linked to?']
answer: the following outcome statements are linked to threshold concepts, or ideas that promote transformation and growth.

question: ['What are the four threshold concepts that are most important for students in uga’s english 11']
answer: our learning outcomes are arranged under four threshold concepts that are most important for students in uga’s english 1101 courses.

question: ['What is the name of each concept?']
answer: each concept includes a bulleted list of the learning objectives, suggesting how students will engage with these ideas in their 1101 courses.

question: ['How many essays will students write?']
answer: students will write a minimum of three essays (1,000-1,500 words or longer) that count for at least 50% of the students' final grades.

question: ['What percentage of their final grade is created by all students?']
answer: in addition to writing papers and doing other work, all students will create a final electronic portfolio that counts as 30% of their final grade.

question: ['What is the norton field guide to writing?']
answer: first-year writing guide (digital version) the norton field guide to writing, 6 th edition primary texts must be chosen by course instructor.

question: ['What must students have passed the english 1101 with?']
answer: to enroll in english 1102, students must have either exempted english 1101 or passed it with a “d” or better.

question: ['What is the average grade of english 1101?']
answer: to graduate, however, students must have earned a grade of “c” in english 1101 and have a combined average grade of “c” in english 1101 and 1102. students therefore are strongly advised not to enroll in english 1102 until they have received a "c" in english 1101. according to the university policy on plus-minus grading, a grade of “c-” will not satisfy the requirement for a “c” in engl 1101; a combined average of “c-“ or 1.7 in english 1101 and 1102 will not satisfy the requirement for a combined average of “c” in the two courses.

question: ["What is the uga bulletin's q&a page on plus-minus "]
answer: for more information on plus-minus grading, refer to the uga bulletin's q&a page on plus-minus grading policies.

question: ['What is the faq #9 particularly relevant to?']
answer: faq #9 is particularly relevant to the requirements of first-year writing.

question: ['What is the core goal of english 1101?']
answer: english 1102 shares the core goals, or learning outcomes, of english 1101, but includes as well other goals specific to the course.

question: ['What is the main focus of english 1101?']
answer: the content also varies: while english 1101 focuses on different varieties of non-fiction writing, english 1102 focuses on informational, analytical, and argumentative writing through literary texts in various genres; as in english 1101, research and critical thinking skills are also emphasized.

question: ['What is the name of the english 1102 class?']
answer: there are different varieties of english 1102 classes and instructors design their own syllabi.

question: ['How many essays will students write in english 1102?']
answer: in english 1102 students will learn to: students will write a minimum of three essays (1,000-1,500 words or longer) that count for at least 50% of the student’s final grade.

question: ['What percentage of their final grade is created by all students?']
answer: in addition to writing papers and doing other work, all students will create a final electronic portfolio that counts as 30% of their final grade.

question: ['What is the primary required for writing guide?']
answer: primary required: first-year writing guide (digital version found on departmental website) text(s) must be chosen by course instructor.

question: ['What is the title of the book that makes literature matter?']
answer: making literature matter , 6th edition.

question: ['What is the option for honors students to substitut for english 1102?']
answer: any standard college dictionary, such as: honors students have the option of substituting for english 1102 either english 1050h (composition and literature) or english 1060h (composition and multicultural literature).

question: ['What is the purpose of each class?']
answer: these courses have the same general goals as other first-year writing courses at the university of georgia, but each class is designed individually by the instructor, often around a special topic.

question: ['What is the emphasis on english for speakers of other languages?']
answer: special sections of english 1101 and 1102 are reserved for students who have a native language other than american english and who can benefit from an english for speakers of other languages (esol) emphasis in these classes.

question: ['What is the name of the class that is not marked differently on their transcripts?']
answer: students enroll only with the permission of the department (pod), but the classes are not marked differently on their transcripts.

question: ['What is the focus of the esol sections?']
answer: the esol sections, like classes for native speakers, focus on writing academic argument in english 1101 and writing about literature in english 1102. first-year writing classes for esol offer non-native speakers opportunities for vocabulary development, for grammar practice, and for orientation to american styles of writing and organization.

question: ['What is the first language of the United States?']
answer: residents of the united states whose first language is not american english, as well as international students, may qualify for these classes.

question: ['What is the name of the first year writing program?']
answer: to determine your eligibility and to obtain a pod to register for the esol classes, contact the first-year writing program office (706-542-2128) or clare reid baeckeroot (clare.reid@uga.edu).

question: ['What is the first year writing program offered?']
answer: in the regular, eight-week "thru term" of summer school, the first-year writing program offers english 1102e, a fully online, asynchronous course.

question: ['What is the standard fyw engl1102 requirement for students in 1102']
answer: students in 1102e meet all the standard fyw engl1102 requirements while completing a series of units (or "modules").

question: ['What is the name of the group that students do not meet during particular class times?']
answer: students work as a cohort between specified dates, but do not meet as a group during particular class times, either online or face-to-face.

question: ['What is the name of the topic version of fyw that is approved in advance by']
answer: experienced instructors may design a special topics version of fyw that is approved in advance by the first-year writing committee.

question: ['What is the name of the course that is marked by a special note in athena']
answer: these courses often focus on topics related to the instructor’s research or scholarly interests, and the sections are marked by a special note in athena.

question: ['What is the standard 1101?']
answer: english 1101s allows students to hone their developing writing skills through community service while still fulfilling the goals of a standard 1101. depending on the focus of the course, 1101s may involve field trips and out-of-class community service as well as community based writing projects.

question: ['What is the ultimate goal of service-learning?']
answer: the ultimate goal of service-learning is to promote students' civic and academic learning while contributing to the public good.

question: ['Where are the fyw digital learning labs located?']
answer: fyw digital learning labs: park 117, 118, 119 the fyw digital learning labs are located on the first floor of the new wing in park hall.

question: ['What is lab 118 open to students and instructors every week?']
answer: lab 118 is open to students and instructors every week day 8:00-5:00 m-f for performing elw-related tasks such as uploading and peer reviewing and for technical assistance with elw.

question: ['What is the name of the lab that has two designated teaching spaces?']
answer: we have two labs designated as teaching spaces: a limited number of laptops will be available for checkout for use in the labs during the class period.

question: ['What is the name of the card that students must bring to lab 118?']
answer: students must bring their uga id card to lab 118 to check out a laptop.

question: ['What is the portfolio of students in a first-year writing course at uga?']
answer: all students in a first-year writing course at uga produce a polished portfolio of their semester's work in the class.

question: ['What is the portfolio project that helps you develop into a proficient writer?']
answer: guidelines for writing the introductory reflective essay (rtf) portfolio grading rubric (rtf) the portfolio project helps you develop into a proficient writer by offering you multiple opportunities to practice and demonstrate to others your mastery of writing as an art.

question: ['How many graded papers will students write in this class?']
answer: in this class, students will write a minimum of three graded papers plus other pieces of writing assigned by the teacher.

question: ['What is the portfolio of written work that each student will be able to write?']
answer: part of each student’s course grade will also be determined by a portfolio of written work.

question: ['What is the final examination?']
answer: the portfolio will count as 30% of your final grade and will replace the final examination as the culminating measure of your achievement in engl 1101 or engl 1102 this semester.

question: ['What is the portfolio of assessments that offer many advantages over other forms of assessment?']
answer: for both students and teachers, portfolios offer many advantages over other forms of assessment.

question: ['What is the first thing that writers gain more control over their writing?']
answer: first-and probably most important, from the student’s point of view-writers gain more control over their writing and therefore over their grades.

question: ['What is the final examination?']
answer: instead of demonstrating your skill in a single essay, the final examination, you will create, select, revise and polish different pieces for the portfolio throughout the semester.

question: ['What is the name of the writing program that you select to include in your portfolio?']
answer: within boundaries established by the first-year writing program, you select the pieces to include in your portfolio; you will have opportunities to consult with your teacher and peers about the portfolio’s contents and to revise those pieces you choose to include; finally, you will have an opportunity to explain the merits of your portfolio as part of the assessment process.

question: ['What is the method of evaluation that teachers use to focus on?']
answer: for the same reasons, teachers also like this method of evaluation: including portfolios in writing assessment allows them to focus on revision, on improvement, and on a process of collaboration among student, teacher, and peers.

question: ['What is the basis of a professional portfolio that can accompany you as you leave the university of']
answer: when you have completed this course, your portfolio will provide you with a readily accessible collection of your writing that can continually grow and change shape, reflecting your achievements in your academic major and, eventually, forming the basis of a professional portfolio that can accompany you as you leave the university of georgia for a further world of work or study.

question: ['What is the name of the first year writing program?']
answer: as stated in the fyw handbook , students in the first-year writing program write a minimum of three graded papers.

question: ['What is the name of the portfolio author?']
answer: for your final assessment, you will compose and submit for evaluation an electronic portfolio that includes the following seven components: a biography of the portfolio author and, if you like, a picture of yourself or other image.

question: ['What is the name of the biography that should provide a short introduction to you?']
answer: the biography should provide a short introduction to you, the author of the portfolio.

question: ['What is the name of the photo that you may include?']
answer: you may include a photo of yourself or an image that relates to ideas discussed in your portfolio.

question: ['What is the goal of your biography?']
answer: the goal of your biography should be to introduce yourself as a writer .

question: ['What is the introductory reflective essay?']
answer: the introductory reflective essay.

question: ['What is the most important element in your portfolio?']
answer: the most important element in your portfolio, the introductory reflective essay (ire) (usually 750-1500 words) ties together all the exhibits in your portfolio; it helps you describe and reflect on your writing processes, with your exhibits providing the supporting evidence .

question: ['What did the course have to do with the revision of two essays?']
answer: two revised essays from the course.

question: ['What are some examples of your best critical thinking, argumentative strategies, prose style and editing']
answer: these pieces provide evidence of your best critical thinking, argumentative strategies, prose style, and editing skills.

question: ['What are the most “finished” pieces of writing?']
answer: they represent your most “finished” pieces of writing.

question: ['What is one revision exhibit that shows your composing process and revision skills?']
answer: one revision exhibit that demonstrates your composing process and revision skills.

question: ['What is the name of the paper that students typically present for this exhibit?']
answer: for this exhibit, students typically present a portion of a paper (e.g., a paragraph or the thesis statement); and demonstrate the development of this piece of writing through several drafts.

question: ['What is the purpose of your writing?']
answer: your task is to clearly show how your writing changed between drafts and to include explaining commentary on your revision process to readers.

question: ['What is one peer review exhibit that shows your work in reviewing or responding to other writers?']
answer: one peer review exhibit that demonstrates your work in reviewing or responding to the work of other writers.

question: ['What is your task to demonstrate?']
answer: again, your task is to demonstrate the quality of your work and to explain your peer review process.

question: ['What is the name of the journal that students have submitted in the past?']
answer: in the past, students have submitted journals, photos with captions, short stories, poems, letters, song lyrics, slideshow presentations, scans of drawings with comments, podcasts, and music files.

question: ['What is the theme of the exhibit?']
answer: some students create new exhibits especially to fit with their portfolio theme.

question: ['What is the overall portfolio rationale for a wild card?']
answer: in thinking about selecting or creating a wild card, consider how it fits into your overall portfolio rationale.

question: ['What is the name of the final portfolio of your instructor?']
answer: while your instructor may have you turn in artifacts to elw for workshopping and peer review, you will turn in your final portfolio to elc under "assignments."

question: ['What is the process of submitting a portfolio in elc?']
answer: there are resources describing the process of submitting a portfolio in elc: a video and a text document.

answer: students can find these resources in their elc course under "content" --> "fyw resources and info"

question: ["How many students are enrolled in uga's first-year writing program?"]
answer: the first-year writing program at uga introduces 4,500-5,000 students a year to college-level academic writing.

question: ['What is the term for english 1101?']
answer: english 1101 is concerned with argumentative discourse, english 1102 with constructing academic arguments through literature.

question: ['What is the name of the online writing class?']
answer: we also offer a wide range of special topics courses, online writing classes, and composition courses.

question: ['What is the capstone project for both courses?']
answer: the capstone project for both courses is an electronic portfolio of student work.

question: ['What is the purpose of eportfolios?']
answer: eportfolios allow students to showcase their best work, to reflect upon their own writing practices, and to present their writing in a persuasive manner to a range of readers.

question: ['What was the final report submitted to the uga first year writing program?']
answer: the uga first year writing program was a member of cohort 2 of the inter/national coalition of electronic portfolio research and in 2007 submitted a final report to that body.

question: ['What was the research topic of the fyw program?']
answer: in 2010-2013, the fyw program participated in cohort 6 of the inter/national coalition of electronic portfolio research; the research topic was assessment.

question: ['What award is awarded for departments and programs 2012?']
answer: also, the program has a history of award-winning accolades such as the usg regents teaching excellence award for departments and programs 2012).

question: ["What award did uga receive for uga's science writing project?"]
answer: at the annual 4c (conference on college composition and communication) meeting, robby nadler, kristen miller (head of the division of biology), and christy desmet received the council on basic writing's award for innovation inny award) for uga's science writing project.

question: ['How many awards does each award receive each year?']
answer: only one award is given each year nationally.

question: ['What was the project involved in the uga writing center?']
answer: a collaboration between the uga writing center, division of biology, first-year writing, and the writing intensive program, the project involved a study of how advanced humanities writers respond to biology lab reports in order to isolate science writing knowledge gaps (2018).

question: ['What is the first year writing program?']

question: ['What is one of the tools that are used to help writers?']

question: ['What is a group of four or more related courses within a major or coherent field of']
answer: an area of emphasis is a group of four or more related courses within a major or coherent field of study.

question: ['What is the current area of emphasis in the english department?']
answer: the english department introduced areas of emphasis to the major in the spring of 2009. our current areas of emphasis are: advanced studies in english , american literature , creative writing , eighteenth-century literature , english language studies , interdisciplinary renaissance studies , humanities computing , medieval literature , multicultural american literature , poetics , rhetoric and composition , and studies in the novel .

question: ['What is the name of the area that you should use as a suggestion for concentration in?']
answer: we advise you to use the areas as suggestions for concentration in a particular genre or field of english studies.

question: ['What is the name of the literary genre that you love?']
answer: do you really love medieval literature or creative writing?

question: ['What is the best way to satisfy all your major requirements?']
answer: by declaring an area of emphasis within your english major, you can now map out the best way to satisfy all your major requirements while still focusing ly on the fields you find most interesting.

question: ['What is the name of each area that has a set of required courses?']
answer: each area has a set of required courses as well as a selection of "emphasis elective" courses from which students may choose.

question: ['What is the concentration that prepares you for continuing your studies at the graduate and professional levels?']
answer: this concentration prepares you for continuing your studies at the graduate and professional levels, whether in law, business, medical school or other programs.

question: ['What is the track used for?']
answer: the track helps specifically with preparation for the gre subject test in english, emphasizing literary theory, advanced writing, and historical coverage.

question: ['What is the name of the study of American literature?']
answer: contact: dr. richard menke extensive study of american literature from its colonial origins to the present, including writers of all races, religions, and nationalities.

question: ['What is the focus of cody marrs?']
answer: contact: dr. cody marrs intense focus on creative writing classes as well as the study of classic and contemporary examples of creative literature.

question: ['aruni kashyap is an area of emphasis in brit']
answer: contact: professor aruni kashyap an area of emphasis in eighteenth-century british literature provides students a grounding in literary studies that can be applied to versatile fields, including law, literary studies, and business.

question: ['What was the age of the novel?']
answer: the age witnessed the creation of the novel as a literary genre, the honing of ethics as a philosophical practice, the emergence of feminist discourse, and the rise of commercial culture and capitalism.

question: ['What age is the age in which we still live?']
answer: the courses in this area will introduce you to the modern age (the age in which we still live) at its inception.

question: ["What is linguistics' sister-concentration?"]
answer: a sister-concentration to linguistics.

question: ['What is the interplay between language and literature?']
answer: in this track, you will examine how english as a language functions and the interplay between language and literature.

question: ['What is the name of the area of emphasis that will bring out your latent english ner']
answer: contact: dr. william kretzschmar this area of emphasis will bring out your latent english nerd.

question: ['What is the ultimate foundation for renaissance studies?']
answer: if you love all things renaissance -- history or the languages or even the fashions -- this cross-departmental concentration provides the ultimate foundation in renaissance (or early modern) studies.

question: ['What is the focus of the area of emphasis?']
answer: contact: dr. sujata iyengar this area of emphasis examines how english studies work in new media and the digital age.

question: ['What is the focus of the british isles?']
answer: focuses on early literatures and languages from the british isles, including work in old english and middle welsh.

question: ['What is the work of peoples historically underrepresented in english curricula?']
answer: combines work in a variety of disciplines and examines the literary and artistic productions of peoples historically under-represented in english curricula.

question: ['What is the name of the poet in theory?']
answer: contact: dr. carmen comeaux poetry in theory and in practice from its ancient roots to the present day.

question: ['What is the focus of susan rosenbaum?']
answer: contact: dr. susan rosenbaum this area of emphasis looks at what writing is and means.

question: ['What is the purpose of the composition?']
answer: in this concentration you will examine how the way a thing is stated or formed affects/reflects meaning within the composition itself and the cultural circumstances that produced it as well.

question: ['What is the name of the book that is a major in english studies?']
answer: students are encouraged to take a 5th course from the following list: elan 4450: teaching writing in the secondary school or jour 3410: new writing and reporting or jour 3410h: news writing and reporting this area of emphasis examines what makes "the novel" unique within english studies, studying examples of the novel from the inception of the genre through contemporary explorations of what the medium can do.

question: ['What are the areas of emphasis intended as?']
answer: contact: dr. richard menke areas of emphasis are primarily intended as a student's self-advisement tools, ways of planning and tracking progress of study within the english major as a whole.

question: ['What is the name of the area of emphasis that students can complete in any given year?']
answer: as such, please note that because of budgetary and staffing constraints, we cannot guarantee that students who have declared an area of emphasis will be able to complete it in any given year.

question: ['What is the name of the student who is a student who is interested in pursuing ']
answer: any student wishing to pursue an area of emphasis should see either the undergraduate coordinator or administrative coordinator for advisement at the start of the third year of study.

question: ['What is the name of the course that may have lower division prerequisites?']
answer: please note the following: courses outside the english major may have lower division prerequisites.

question: ['What is the prerequisite for a course outside of the english major?']
answer: check the university bulletin to find out what prerequisites you may need in order to enroll in courses outside of the english major.

question: ['What is another note that if many graduate level courses are accepted for different areas of emphasis,']
answer: also note: while many graduate level courses are accepted for various areas of emphasis, only 3 graduate level courses in total may be applied toward an undergraduate degree at the university of georgia.

question: ['What is the name of the area of emphasis that students may petition for?']
answer: for all areas of emphasis, if students feel that a course they have taken for the english major should apply towards an area of emphasis, they may petition the undergraduate committee and appropriate area faculty for the course's inclusion within their area of emphasis work.

question: ['What is the name of the professor at the university of florida?']
answer: changying "charlie" li adjunct professor of engineering adjunct professor of computer science phd: pennsylvania state university, 2006 dr. li is a professor in agricultural ai and automation at the university of florida in gainesville with an adjunct professor appointment with uga.

question: ['What is the name of his research group?']
answer: his research group is developing innovative sensing and automation technologies to help provide safe and high-quality food, fiber, feed and fuel to sustain the world’s growing population.

question: ["What is the name of the team that's developing a robotic system?"]
answer: he currently leads a team of researchers that's developing a robotic system of all-terrain rovers and unmanned aerial drones that can more quickly and accurately gather and analyze genetic data on plants.

question: ["What is another example of dr. li's recent research projects?"]
answer: another example of dr. li's recent research projects is the development of the berry impact recording device, or "bird."

question: ['What is the name of the device that rides along with berries in packing plants?']
answer: the device rides along with berries in packing plants while its sensors record the bumps and bruises inflicted on the fruit.

question: ['What is the name of the bird that helps engineers design gentler harvesting and packing methods?']
answer: the data gathered by bird helps engineers design gentler harvesting and packing methods so more high-quality fruit makes its way to grocery stores.

question: ['What is the name of the research focus?']
answer: other information of note: research focus: phenomics and plant robotics contact information cyli@uga.edu office: 712f boyd research and education center other information professional website: home page directory soc leadership faculty graduate students staff administration

question: ["What is a master's degree program designed for students who seek a broad training in"]
answer: master of applied mathematical sciences computer science option overview of degree this is a professional master's degree program designed for students who seek a broad training in applied computational/quantitative methods as preparation for professional employment in business, government, or industry.

question: ['What is the core curriculum of maths courses offered by the three maths departments?']
answer: students in this program take a core curriculum of courses offered by the three mathematical science departments from the franklin college of arts and sciences .

question: ['What is the name of the program that students complete?']
answer: computer science (csci) mathematics (math) statistics (stat) students complete an interdisciplinary program of study which allows a combination of expertise in computation with a chosen field of application.

question: ['How many semester hours of graduate course work must be required for the program of study?']
answer: the program of study must consist of 33 semester hours of graduate course work.

question: ['How many hours of basic core courses are included in the program?']
answer: in the school of computing option, the program includes 10 hours of basic core courses, at least 20 hours of csci 6000- or 8000-level courses, and 3 hours for a technical report.

question: ['What is the language requirement for foreign language?']
answer: there is no foreign language requirement.

question: ['What is the math department available to accommodate students with different career goals?']
answer: to accommodate students with different career goals, other options are available in the mathematics department.

question: ['What is the program designed to meet the need for technical specialists?']
answer: the program is designed to meet the need for technical specialists who can use computation, applied mathematics, analysis, and statistics to solve complex, quantitative, real-world problems.

question: ['What is the name of the student who prepares a technical report?']
answer: as part of the program of study, each student prepares a technical report (in lieu of a thesis).

question: ['What is intended to be similar to the type of report that one might expect to prepare after graduation']
answer: this gives the student an opportunity to apply course work, and is intended to be similar to the type of report one may expect to prepare when employed after graduation.

question: ['What is the name of the prerequisite courses that are required to qualify for admission to the program?']
answer: admission requirements all candidates for this degree must satisfy the following four requirements to qualify for admission to the program: 1. prerequisite courses (as described in the graduate school bulletin, or the equivalent).

question: ['What is the introduction to algebra 3 hours?']
answer: course number course title semester hours math2200 analytic geometry and calculus 4 hours math2210,2210l integral calculus 4 hours math 3000 introduction to linear algebra 3 hours csci1301 introduction to computing and programming (alt.

question: ['What is the name of the software development that is based on 4 hours csc']
answer: csci 7010 ) 4 hours csci1302 software development 4 hours csci2610 discrete mathematics for computer science 4 hours csci2720 data structures 4 hours 2. graduate record examination (gre) test scores are required for admission consideration.

question: ['What is the minimum number of letters of recommendation required?']
answer: 3. three letters of recommendation are required, preferably written by university professors familiar with your academic work and potential.

question: ['What letter is acceptable if the student has work experience?']
answer: if the student has work experience, one letter from their supervisor is acceptable.

question: ['What is the ability to harness the power of data for informed decision making?']
answer: ms in data science overview of degree in today's data-driven world, the ability to harness the power of data for informed decision making has become a critical skill.

question: ['What is the demand for professionals with expertise in data science?']
answer: as organizations across industries increasingly rely on data to drive innovation and stay competitive, the demand for professionals with expertise in data science has surged.

question: ["What is a master's degree in data science?"]
answer: a master's degree in data science is a comprehensive and advanced program designed to equip students with the knowledge, skills, and tools necessary to excel in this dynamic and rapidly evolving field.

question: ["What is the uga master's degree in data science?"]
answer: the uga master’s degree in data science is an interdisciplinary program that is jointly offered by the department of statistics and the school of computing.

question: ['What is the foundation for data science?']
answer: it will provide the students with a strong foundation in data science, covering algorithms, distributed systems, database management, and machine learning from the school of computing , and regression, time-series analysis, design of experiments, statistical learning, and bayesian statistics from statistics .

question: ['What is the specificity of the data scientists?']
answer: it is tailored to individuals who aspire to become data scientists, analysts, or leaders in the field of data-driven decision-making.

question: ['What is the name of the software that students will know how to develop?']
answer: students graduating with the degree will know how to develop software, design and maintain databases, process data in distributed environments, analyze the data using techniques from statistics, data mining and machine learning, provide visualizations of the data or the results of analysis, and assist decision makers.

question: ['What will the program include in the program?']
answer: the program will include practical application of acquired knowledge and skills in the form of a master’s project course.

question: ['What is the curriculum consists of?']
answer: curriculum the curriculum consists of at least 30 credit hours of resident graduate coursework.

question: ['How many credit hours of coursework must be open only to graduate students?']
answer: this includes the following five items: at least 12 credit hours of core csci graduate coursework at the 6000-level (see “core curriculum” below); at least 8 credit hours of advanced csci graduate coursework at the 6000/8000- level (see “advanced coursework” below); the above (items 1 & 2) must include 12 credit hours of coursework open only to graduate students, exclusive of 6950 and 8990, as per graduate school policy; @6000 level must be graduate student only course and not used in the core curriculum.

question: ["How many credit hours of csci 7300 master's thesis are required?"]
answer: at least 1 credit hour of csci 8990 research seminar (see “research seminar” below); at least 6 credit hours of csci 7000 master’s research (see master’s research below); at least 3 credit hours of csci 7300 master's thesis (see master's thesis below) typically, full-time students will take 9 to 15 hours per semester.

question: ["What is the name of the student's major professor?"]
answer: a program of study should be a coherent and logical whole; it requires the approval of the student's major professor, the student's advisory committee, and the school's graduate coordinator.

question: ['What is the grade of c+ or lower?']
answer: note: no course with a grade of c+ or lower may be included on the student’s program of study (see the graduate bulletin for other gpa constraints).

question: ['What is the core curriculum?']
answer: core curriculum (item #1) at least one course from each of the following three groups must be taken: group 1: theory csci 6470 algorithms csci 6480 approximation algorithms csci 6610 automata and formal languages group 2: software design csci 6050 software engineering csci 6370 database management csci 6570 compilers group 3: system design csci 6720 computer systems architecture csci 6730 operating systems csci 6760 computer networks: technology and application csci 6780 distributed computing systems the core curriculum consists of a total of 12 graduate credit hours.

question: ['What is the core competency foundational computer science knowledge in the core areas?']
answer: core competency foundational computer science knowledge (core competency) in the core areas (groups 1, 2, and 3, above) must be exhibited by each student and certified by the student’s advisory committee.

question: ['What is the name of the core curriculum?']
answer: this takes the form of achievement in core curriculum and completion of a short essay in their chosen area of research demonstrating technical writing and organization skills.

question: ['What must be achieved for the three core courses?']
answer: a grade average of at least 3.30 (e.g., b+, b+, b+) must be achieved for the three core courses.

question: ['What is the grade average for students below the average?']
answer: students below this average may take an additional core course and achieve a grade average of at least 3.15 (e.g., b+, b+, b, b).

question: ['What is the information sheet for all prerequisite courses?']
answer: before taking any courses at uga, we recommend carefully reviewing the course information sheet (cis) for all prerequisite courses to ensure you are adequately prepared.

question: ['What is the csci 1301 cis?']
answer: for example, if you plan on taking software development (csci 1302), you should first review the learning outcomes, major topics covered, and their associated knowledge levels in the csci 1301 cis .

question: ['What is the name of the course that you would need to take?']
answer: if your introductory course was taught in python, you would need to take csci 1301 at uga to build up your foundational java knowledge before moving to csci 1302. if the learning outcomes for a prerequisite course are unfamiliar and/or the major topics weren’t covered at the required knowledge level at your previous institution, you are not ready to move into the next course.

question: ['What is the name of the course that you should take to build your foundational knowledge before moving']
answer: instead, you should start by taking a course at the appropriate level to build your foundational knowledge before moving ahead.

answer: remember, pushing forward without adequate preparation can lead to a much larger setback than starting in the right class .

question: ['What is a great place to start?']
answer: click a link below to jump directly to a course you are considering: csci 1300 : introduction to programming with python if you are a non-major or are considering a computer science degree, minor, or certificate but are unsure if it is right for you, this is a great place to begin.

question: ['What is the course that does not fill any major requirements?']
answer: the course has no prerequisites and is a gentler introduction to programming than csci 1301. csci 1300 does not fill any major requirements.

question: ['What is the name of the elective?']
answer: it is taken only as an elective.

question: ['What is the introduction to computing and programming prerequisite?']
answer: csci 1301 : introduction to computing and programming prerequisite: math 1113 (precalculus) if you are a computer science major but haven’t taken an equivalent course at the college level or if your introductory course was not taught in java, you should start here.

question: ['What does this course do not assume you have prior knowledge of?']
answer: this course does not assume you have any prior cs knowledge.

question: ['What is the name of the experience that is a prior experience of the experience?']
answer: however, any prior experience will be beneficial.

question: ['What is the csci 1301 course information sheet?']
answer: if you still aren’t sure if this is the right course for you, take a look at the csci 1301 course information sheet for more details about the course.

question: ['What is the prerequisite for csci 1301?']
answer: csci 1302 : software development prerequisite: csci 1301 if you completed csci 1301 at another institution (or in high school) and you received uga credit for the course, we still recommend that you review the csci 1301 course information sheet and speak with your academic advisor before taking this course.

question: ['What is the course a follow-up to?']
answer: the course is a rigorous follow-up to csci 1301 taught in java.

question: ['What is the name of the course information sheet?']
answer: it covers the topics listed in the course information sheet at a deep level and students are expected to be able to implement software solutions that incorporate all of the topics from csci 1301 along with new topics in csci 1302 in a unix terminal environment.

question: ['How long is the time spent on reviewing concepts from csci 1301.']
answer: there is little time spent on reviewing concepts from csci 1301. however, your instructors will send out instructions outlining how you can review and practice your programming skills a few weeks before the course begins.

question: ['What is the email that they send to you?']
answer: keep an eye out for their email and make sure you take their advice!

question: ['What is the csci 1302 course information sheet?']
answer: csci 1730 : systems programming prerequisite: csci 1302 if you completed csci 1301 and csci 1302 at another institution and you received credit for both courses, we recommend that you review the csci 1302 course information sheet and speak with your academic advisor before taking this course.

question: ['What is the textbook used in csci 1301?']
answer: we also recommend that you review chapters 1 through 12 in the textbook that is used in csci 1301 ( java: an introduction to problem solving and programming, 8 th edition, isbn: 978-0134462035).

question: ['What is considered a lower-level language than java?']
answer: this course focuses on the c programming language which is considered a lower-level (r to the hardware) language than java.

question: ['What is the name of the csci 1730 students expected to have in the']
answer: students taking csci 1730 are expected to have significant experience in a unix command-line environment and be well-versed in csci 1302 concepts.

question: ['What is the name of the online tutorial for unix/linux?']
answer: we recommend that you complete the online tutorials for unix/linux at https://info-ee.surrey.ac.uk/teaching/unix/ and the built-in emacs tutorial (or any online tutorial for emacs) prior to your first day of class in csci 1730. the knowledge gained from this course is critical for success in our other systems-level courses like operating systems, architecture, and computer networking.

question: ['What is the prerequisite for csci 2610?']
answer: csci 2610 : discrete mathematics for computer science required prerequisite: math 1113 (precalculus) recommended prerequisite: csci 1301 students in discrete mathematics will start to build the theoretical foundation for other courses in the discipline.

answer: topics taught in this course pop up regularly throughout the cs curriculum.

answer: discrete mathematics at uga puts a higher emphasis on proof-writing techniques as they are an important skill in csci 2670 and certain courses throughout the curriculum.

question: ['What is the name of the course that you should start here?']
answer: if you are a computer science major but haven’t taken an equivalent course at the college level or if your discrete mathematics course did not cover proof-writing techniques, you should start here.

question: ['What is the csua experiential learning program?']
answer: computer science undergraduate assistant (csua) experiential learning program the csua experiential learning program aims to leverage the success of undergraduates who have completed the course in which they serve and wish to share their knowledge and abilities with their peers.

question: ['What is the purpose of experiential learning?']
answer: through experiential learning, participants provide valuable knowledge, insight, and learning strategies for both the students and the instructional team they work with, while also furthering their own mastery of related material.

question: ['What is the name of the csua experiential learning program?']
answer: the csua experiential learning program has one paid track: undergraduate teaching assistant (uta): uta participants work directly with the instructional team, including graduate teaching assistants (gtas), to help with traditional teaching assistant activities, including assignment assessment and office hours, as needed.

question: ['What are utas challenged to reinforce their knowledge about?']
answer: utas are regularly challenged to reinforce they knowledge about course material and ancillary concepts by grading assignments and helping create and test automated evaluation tools for assignments.

question: ['What other job requirements may apply?']
answer: additional job requirements may apply.

question: ['What is the grade of the course that the participants must have taken at the university of georg']
answer: participants must have taken the course they're assigned to at the university of georgia and received a satisfactory grade.

question: ['What is the competitive application process?']
answer: participants are chosen based on a competitive application process, which includes a holistic look at the student's application, including, but not limited to, their prior experience, performance in the assigned course, gpa, and scheduling availability.

answer: by earning both a bachelor’s degree and a master’s degree in five years or less, students can save time and money while positioning themselves for success after graduation.

question: ['How many credit hours of graduate csci core classes will count toward both undergraduate and']
answer: 12 credit hours of graduate csci core classes will count toward both undergraduate and graduate degree when in the pathway, however, once a pathway student is accepted into the ms program, then these students will need to obtain 12 credit hours of graduate student only coursework with three 4 credit hour advanced course work, in 6000 and or 8000 csci courses.

question: ['What is the bs.ms cybersecurity and privacy pathway?']
answer: bs.ms csci pathway (nonthesis) bs.ms cybersecurity and privacy pathway (nonthesis) double dawg student tutorial application process a student wishing to pursue the dual degree must first submit an application to be admitted to the program pathway .

question: ['What is the name of the pathway that students should apply for?']
answer: students should apply for the program pathway in athena (student>double dawgs pathways) and complete the pathway application below to be considered.

question: ['What is the name of the course that students must have completed?']
answer: to be eligible, students must have completed 60 - 90 credit hours and have completed the following courses with a grade of c or better course name description math 2250 calculus i (differential calculus) csci 1301 introduction to computing and programming csci 1302 software development csci/math 2610 discrete mathematics for computer science csci 2670 introduction to theory of computing csci 2720 data structures students who are currently enrolled in csci 2670 theory and csci 2720 data structures can apply now.

question: ['What is the name of the admissions committee that will consider the admissions to the pathway?']
answer: admissions to the pathway for students who have not yet completed csci 2670 and csci 2720 will be considered on a case-by-case basis by a faculty admissions committee.

question: ['What is the name of the course that is not yet completed?']
answer: students who have not yet completed these courses and are denied admission will be encouraged to try again after completing the courses.

question: ['What is the cumulative gpa of the student?']
answer: in addition, the student must have a cumulative gpa of 3.0 or higher at the time of application.

question: ['What does acceptance to the pathway do not guarantee?']
answer: acceptance to the pathway does not guarantee acceptance into the graduate program.
